b5953de161e07c36c49c96a3c48a128d (17:16): haha, yes that would probably fit her/their ideas of what HTML5 should be
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:17): the W3C has a long history of fucking up HTML by going off into la-la land for a few years while the world evolves without them
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (17:17): has never heard of HTML Plus before...
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:17): HTML+ was one such effort (between HTML 1.0 and HTML 2.0)
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:17): HTML 2.0 was basically "hey, let's see what browsers have actually implemented while we weren't looking"
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:17): then they made HTML 3.0, which was similarly delusional

61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:18): then they threw that away and made HTML 3.2, which was basically "hey, let's see what else browsers have actually implmeented while we were busy masturbating"
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:19): then they made HTML 4.0, which shockingly wasn't completely horrible (though it was horribly underspecified)
b5953de161e07c36c49c96a3c48a128d (17:19): you've been around all of those discussions or you just red the "history of html, a different perspective"
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:19): then they gave up on HTML altogether, to the point of ignoring all W3C process and refusing to issue errata or integrate existing errata into point releases
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:20): and started whole hog on XHTML
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:20): XHTML 1.0 is literally HTML 4 + a few useless slashes
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:21): oh, and a new MIME type and draconian error handling, which nobody uses (hi Sam)
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:21): then XHTML 1.1, which nobody uses
b5953de161e07c36c49c96a3c48a128d (17:21): so is HTML5 a w3c idea or a community (vendors) idea ?
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:21): then XHTML 2, which they spent almost a decade on and finally put out to pasture this year
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:22): HTML5 was a community-led effort of browser vendors, standards wonks (like Hixie), and other interested parties
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:22): all formerly quite active within the W3C
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:22): they begged and pleaded with the W3C to let them work on HTML5 (or 4.1, or whatever, anything but XHTML 2)
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:23): so they formed their own working group (WHATWG)
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (17:23): and started from scratch (since the license of the HTML 4 specification forbids derivative works by non-W3C organizations)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:24): so then it seems this HTML+RDFa effort may just be the next round of crap to be attempted during the overall development of HTML, that will likely eventually die out like the rest.
